Dear Ms. Smillie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster Parent Information
Section (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the following
Description information before the placement or replacement of a child… (a-j)
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not provide mental health or behavioral information
about child to foster parents, when seeking placement.
Investigation Complainant was contacted by phone and email on 4/18/23.
Complainant responded via email on 4/19/23 stating they had
previous placement of Youth A and were familiar with his
behaviors and mental health needs. Complainant indicated she
filed the complainant as she was aware of the agency contacting
potential foster parents for placement and not providing
information about all of Youth A's behavioral issues and mental
health needs. Complainant stated they received some information
about Youth A prior to placement. However, he displayed
additional defiant and aggressive behaviors after being in their
home for a few weeks. Complainant stated they did not feel
enough information was provided about Youth A before accepting
placement. Complainant did not recall receiving or signing a
placement outline detailing information about Youth A.
Chief Administrator was contacted by phone on 4/18/23. An email
was also sent as the phone number on file was incorrect. Chief
Administrator responded by email stating that placements for
Youth A had been challenging lately, due to increasing needs.
Chief Administrator provided contact information for the staff
identified by Complainant.
Supervisor was interviewed via Teams on 4/20/23. Supervisor
reported Youth A had several moves over the past few months.
This occurred after an adoptive placement was unsuccessful.
Youth A moved to one foster home, in which his behaviors
increased and he was taken to the hospital, then placed in a
mental health/behavior stabilization program, before returning to
the foster home. The foster parents ultimately decided not to
maintain placement. Youth A has since been in several foster
homes. Youth A had a lengthy trauma history, difficult at school,
mental health needs, and behavioral needs. All of which seemed
to escalate after the failed adoptive placement. Supervisor
reported that she and another staff are often the ones that contact
potential adoptive parents. Typically, a placement request
2

document is completed by the foster care worker. Then potential
foster parents are contacted with preliminary information. If the
foster parent is interested, additional details about the youth are
provided, typically through phone conversations. Supervisor
stated she knew it was important to share all of Youth A's history
with potential placements. But she also wanted to protect his
privacy by only fully sharing with those that were interested after
the preliminary information. Supervisor and DCWL discussed
different ways to document what information was provided to the
interested foster parents and when. The use of a case contact,
indicating the placement request paperwork was reviewed with the
foster parent would be acceptable. Or documenting the names of
the families on the placement request itself. However, a
placement outline (DHHS-3307) should still be completed when a
child is placed in a foster home, as this form captures the foster
parent’s signature to indicate they fully received the required
information. Supervisor acknowledged the agency was cited for
rule 417 during the December 2022 annual review. This citation
was due to the agency not documenting the required information
was provided to foster parents at placement. Supervisor reported
their CAP was implemented in January 2023, which included
utilizing calendar reminders for staff to complete the required
documentation (DHHS-3307). Supervisor reported that overall,
this process has worked well. However, regarding Youth A’s case,
Supervisor stated she took ownership over the missed documents
from the file. Supervisor indicated they were behind with
paperwork while managing placement crises with Youth A.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via Teams on
4/28/23. FCW reported that she does not have much involvement
with locating placements. Typically, FCW completes a placement
request form with information about the youth and provides it to
licensing. A licensing worker then contacts families for placement
and shares some information about the youth. Supervisor would
then schedule a meeting with Youth A’s team and the potential
foster parent to discuss the youth’s needs further. FCW was
uncertain about how this meeting or any phone contact were
documented. FCW was informed that DHHS-3307 Placement
Outlines, could not be located in Youth A’s file. FCW reported
using 3307’s to document the rule requirement. However,
regarding Youth A, his frequent replacements and escalating
needs resulted in FCW getting behind in completing some
paperwork. FCW stated she was aware she needed to get caught
up and planned to have Supervisor assist.
Documents reviewed:
3

• Youth A's case file was reviewed on 4/18/23 and found that
Youth A had six placements over the past eight months.
None of the six placements had documentation of
information provided to the foster parent. Typically, this
information is documented on the DHHS 3307 placement
outline. No 3307's were found in the case file. Case
contacts were also reviewed for any documentation of
information provided to the foster parents. However, no
information was found that would satisfy the rule
requirement.
• Placement request document from BCS was reviewed. The
document outlined Youth A's behaviors and needs, which
were consistent with information found throughout Youth
A's case file. However, the form did not document which
foster parents this information was provided to.
• Supervisor provided a spreadsheet, which is used to
document the homes contacted regarding placement.
However, none of the six homes where Youth A was
placed, are listed on this spreadsheet.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as they did not document
the mental health or behavioral information that was provided to
previous foster parents of Youth A, as required by part (g) of this
rule. In addition, during a review of the file, it was determined the
agency did not document that any of the information required by
parts (a-j) of this rule were provided to foster parents. This was
true for all six of the youth's placements over the past eight
months.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/22/22 RENEWAL, CAP Approved 1/17/23.
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
